sub_topic: Determining the degree sequence of a graph.
message_1: Consider a graph with 7 vertices and degree sequence {2,2,2,3,3,4,4}. Is this degree sequence possible? If so, draw the graph; if not, explain why not.
message_2:
Yes, this degree sequence is possible. We can construct a graph with the given degree sequence as follows:

Label the vertices as A, B, C, D, E, F, and G.

1. Connect vertex A (degree 4) to vertices B, C, D, and E.
2. Connect vertex B (degree 2) to vertices A and F.
3. Connect vertex C (degree 2) to vertices A and F.
4. Connect vertex D (degree 3) to vertices A, E, and G.
5. Connect vertex E (degree 3) to vertices A, D, and G.
6. Connect vertex F (degree 2) to vertices B and C.
7. Connect vertex G (degree 4) to vertices D, E, F, and G.

The resulting graph has the desired degree sequence {2,2,2,3,3,4,4}:

A: connected to B, C, D, E (degree 4)
B: connected to A, F (degree 2)
C: connected to A, F (degree 2)
D: connected to A, E, G (degree 3)
E: connected to A, D, G (degree 3)
F: connected to B, C, G (degree 3)
G: connected to D, E, F (degree 3)
